bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A. Diaz Albertini, July 18, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses his ongoing research, the Cornwell painting, "Conquerors of Yellow Fever," Kissinger's stroke and Blossom Reed's heart attack.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A. Diaz Albertini, July 18, 1941
div1.p:
Enclose photo & copy letter to
librarian Finlay Institute
6/29/41 My dear Dr. Albertini

I hope that you are receiving the Proceedings of the Staff
meetings of the Mayo Clinic which I asked to have sent to you.
I have been continuing my search for unpublished data
regarding the conquest of yellow fever. I spent some time
in Washington where, through the help of General
J. R Kean and former Surgeon General Ireland I
unearthed the written hand-written records of the
Columbia Barracks Post Hospital, also manymuch of the
correspondence between Surgeon General Sternberg and
the U. S. army yellow fever commission in Havana.

on June 2, 1941 the Wyeth Company, a large old the
reputable American pharmaceutical house, unveiled a very
interesting painting depicting the “Conquerors of Yellow
Fever”. You will be pleased to know that Dr. Finlay has
been rightly given a very prominent place in the painting.
I was present at the unveiling which was done by
Walter Reed's daughter. Kissinger was present also.
Two days later he had a severe stroke and was
completely paralyzed on his right side; his vision and speech
are also affected. I do hope he escapes long
suffering. I have just heard that Miss Blossom
Reed, who unveiled the painting, has just suffered
a severe heart attack. Both of these constitute a
tragic aftermath to an inspiring ceremony.

When I was in Havana Miss Agramonte
(Sr. Rodriguez - Leon) loaned me the enclosed photograph
in which her father & Drs. Guiteras & Finlay appear. She
asked if I could find out who some of the other
men were. The photograph was labelled “Commission
of Infectious Diseases - Mariel 1901, Pinar del Rio”
and was in her fathers collection. Gen. Kean could not
recognize the others. May I ask if you would kindly
study the photograph & return it to me. Perhaps you
can recognize some of those present.

I am continuing my attempts to try to raise
enough money to memorialize properly the site of
Camp Lazear & the little Building number one which
we discovered. I do hope the impending war
won't stop my efforts.

I have hunted everywhere for a history ( of Military Hospital
number one but could find nothing in this, country. Last May when I
visited the library at the Finlay Institute with Drs. Ramos and
Recio the librarian showed me a copy of a book about the
hospital. I told him I was very anxious to borrow it
to have photostatic copies made but would first see if I
could find it in this country. I have searched the Congressional
Library in Washington, the Surgeon General's Library, and The New York
Public Library and others but have been unable to find it.
I am writing the librarian at the Finlay Institute
asking if he would be willing to send me his book by
registered mail so that I could copy it. If you could help
me in this matter I would appreciate it very much
indeed.

It was so pleasant to meet you again
and I should like to be able to entertain you
if you could ever visit the Mayo Clinic.

Very Sincerely yours
Very Sincerely yours
